I'd like to add that even though some code may seem simpler if it is not
written with tests in mind, that still doesn't seem like a good enough
excuse for not writing testable code.  After all, lots of things seem
complicated to novices, but what we're talking about here is actually making
things simpler:  the tests.  They may not appear simpler, but they are, in
the sense that it's easier to test things.  This translates into code that's
more robust, since the tests can find more problems.  In my opinion, testing
is a requirement, not a "nice-to-have", and thus making the tests simpler
should be part of the design.

Mark

>> I concur.  I've found that testable code exhibits certain composable 
>> properties that foster interface-based design.  For example, the 
>> assembly of a few simple objects to perform a more complex 
>> task allows 
>> any of the objects to be mocked.  In turn, by refactoring designs to 
>> extract complex static relationships into interface-based 
>> compositions, 
>> the design becomes more open to extension, but closed to 
>> modification. 
>> So, I'll up the ante and claim that designs may change as a 
>> side effect 
>> of writing tests.  This is the essence of test-first design.
>> 
>> Mike
>> 
> 
> 
> If these are indeed compex relationships then it may well be the case that
> refactoring the code is an appropriate course of action. Not all
> relationships *are* complex! In my experience it is better to keep the
code
> simple where ever possible. I might understand what is going on - but my
> code maintanence successors may not.
> 
> Changing the code to suit your tests could quite easily cause your code to
> have a stitled and difficult to read style - especially to less
experienced
> coders. My goal is always clarity in coding style. 
> 

Agreed - simplicity is paramount.  Toward that end, if through testing 
the code a simpler design takes form, then all the better.  The point is 
that testing may be the catalyst for rethinking the design, and 
refactoring the code, to better serve the intended clients.  In other 
words, there can be a positive feedback loop between design, coding, and 
testing.

Mike
